newsitem.title: ITALY: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Tuesday July 22.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Tuesday July 22.

text.p: Following are some of the top headlines in leading Italian newspapers.

* Democratic Party of the Left leader Massimo D'Alema said he had been misunderstood by newspapers reporting he criticised opposition head Silvio Berlusconi for wanting political impunity. D'Alema said he was only repeating his political stance (all).

* In an interview, treasury minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi said Europe had never been as close to union as now and Italy was standing a better chance of meeting the criteria for joining EMU since the country had carried out more structural reforms than most of its European partners (Corriere della Sera).

* Preliminary data from five sample cities showed consumer price inflation rose 1.5-1.6 percent year-on-year in July compared with 1.4 percent in June. Prime minister Romano Prodi said he was very satisfied with the results but reaffirmed the need to find an agreement on welfare state reforms (all).
* Banking group Ambroveneto said its assets under management and investment funds rose 67 percent to 24.650 trillion lire at end-June 1997 from 14.754 trillion on June 30 1996.

* In an interview, banking group Istituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino's chairman Giovanni Zandano said 40 Italian banks are facing a critical situation. Zandano also said that whereas abroad mergers helped to reduce costs, in Italy they tended to double them and that the country's laws regarding labour lacked flexibility (Corriere della Sera).
* Italy's Finance Ministry said tax revenue for the first five months of 1997 totalled 200.279 trillion lire, unchanged from the same period a year earlier (all).

* Paolo Cantarella, Fiat chief executive officer, said the group plans to invest a total of one billion dollars in the five-year period from 1997 to 2002 in all the company's projects in India. Fiat's Indian unit should manifacture a million "world cars" or Palios a year by the turn of the century (all).
* A study by economic research body ISCO showed confidence in the economy among Italian households rose in July to 114.1 from 108.9 in June (Sole 24 Ore).
Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
